name: Nico Ranalli
comment info: Heightened Summer Heat: I notice that as time increases, and therefore comes closer to current day, the average temperature increases as well. From 1951-1980, the distribution of summer temperatures in the Northern Hemisphere was approximately normally distributed with the majority of days within the “normal” temperature range. However from 2013-2023, the graph has drastically shifted to the right with the majority of days in the “hot” and “extremely hot” temperature categories. This graph is right skewed. The first graph spans over 29 years while the second only shows data from a ten year period. I wonder, if the graphs were created on a ten year basis (for example, 1991-2001, 2002-2012, 2013-2023) would the graphs change as dramatically? I wonder what major inventions have led to this climate change? Could it include farming, cars, increased production? I wonder, is this data reflected similarly from other nations? Does this data match that of the southern hemisphere? I also am wondering, what specific temperatures constitute the categories “cold, normal, hot, and extremely hot”? As a New Hampshire resident, this directly impacts me and my community through our climate. The data shows summer temperatures of the Northern Hemisphere are increasingly warming up, impacting our lives in the summer. This climate change does not just impact what clothes we wear in the summer, it impacts available water, food availability, and even power use/consumption.

I notice that average summer temperatures in Northern Hemisphere have increased significantly since the 1950s. Increasing temperatures due to climate change can lead to a multitude of challenges for both humans and the environment we live in. In communities around the world, extreme heat events can pose health risks, such as the elderly, children, and those with pre-existing health conditions. Rising temperatures can also exacerbate issues like drought, water scarcity, and wildfires, impacting agriculture, biodiversity, and overall ecosystem health. Additionally, warmer temperatures can contribute to the melting of polar ice caps and glaciers, leading to sea level rise and coastal erosion, which threatens coastal communities and infrastructure. Addressing the impacts of rising temperatures requires concerted efforts at both local and global levels, including mitigation strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adaptation measures to build resilience to the changes already underway.

name: Daniel Tsemekhman
comment info:
Interesting title: Visualizing the Alarming Rise in Northern Hemisphere Summer Temperatures

The two area graphs provide a striking visual comparison of summer temperature distributions in the Northern Hemisphere across different 30-year periods, revealing an alarming warming trend. The 1951-1980 graph approximates a normal distribution, with temperatures symmetrically clustered around the mean of 1°C above baseline. Fast forward to 2013-2023, and the curve has shifted significantly to the right and flattened out, with the peak now around 1.5°C above baseline. From living in San Luis Obispo, California, I've witnessed the changing climate firsthand, with summers growing hotter and more prolonged.
Comparing the tails reveals an alarming trend: the former upper extreme of 2°C from 1951-1980 is now squarely in the bulk of the 2013-2023 distribution. In San Luis Obispo, we've experienced the consequences, from severe droughts to extended wildfire seasons. Graphs like these make the reality of climate change starkly visible, underscoring the urgency of addressing this warming trend. They remind us of the need for our community to take action and build a more sustainable future.

name: Daniel Tsemekhman
comment info:
Interesting title: Visualizing the Alarming Rise in Northern Hemisphere Summer Temperatures

The two area graphs provide a striking visual comparison of summer temperature distributions in the Northern Hemisphere across different 30-year periods, revealing an alarming warming trend. The 1951-1980 graph approximates a normal distribution, with temperatures symmetrically clustered around the mean of 1°C above baseline. Fast forward to 2013-2023, and the curve has shifted significantly to the right and flattened out, with the peak now around 1.5°C above baseline. From living in San Luis Obispo, California, I've witnessed the changing climate firsthand, with summers growing hotter and more prolonged.
Comparing the tails reveals an alarming trend: the former upper extreme of 2°C from 1951-1980 is now squarely in the bulk of the 2013-2023 distribution. In San Luis Obispo, we've experienced the consequences, from severe droughts to extended wildfire seasons. Graphs like these make the reality of climate change starkly visible, underscoring the urgency of addressing this warming trend. They remind us of the need for our community to take action and build a more sustainable future.

Edit: Said there was an error uploading

Global warming not only disrupts our daily routines but also poses serious threats to our safety and health.

name: Emma
comment info:
As I study the graphs, I can't help but notice a significant change in how summer temperatures have evolved over time. Back in the 1950s to 1980s, the temperature distribution was like a symphony, with most of the notes clustered around the "Normal" range. It felt like summers followed a predictable rhythm during that era. But fast forward to 2013-2023, and it's like the music has changed entirely. The peak has shifted to "Hot," and there's this long, drawn-out crescendo reaching into "Extremely hot" temperatures. It's like summers have become more unpredictable, with heatwaves becoming the new norm.

I wonder what's behind this dramatic shift. What's causing this sudden change in temperature patterns? Is it something we're doing, or is it nature's own rhythm? I'm also curious about how different parts of the Northern Hemisphere are experiencing these changes. Are some places feeling the heat more intensely than others?

This shift to hotter summers has real consequences for us because it means farmers might struggle with crops, and we might find ourselves cranking up the air conditioning more often, leading to higher electricity bills. And let's not forget the health risks, especially for those who are vulnerable to extreme heat. 

These graphs paint a picture of a world where summers are getting hotter, and it's up to us to tune in and take action.  A catchy headline could be "Hotter Summers Ahead: Graphs Sound the Alarm on Temperature Surge in the Northern Hemisphere".

The visualisation illustrates the shift in the summer temperature pattern of the Northern hemisphere across the intensity of heat levels, for identified year-slices. Great wonder about how the data was collected.  The data is from Goddard Institute for Space Studies (GISS) surface air temperature analysis.  Here is the link to the journal article that analyzed the temperature data:https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1205276109.

name: Claudia Vieira
comment info:
I notice first that the average temperatures have increased consistently over the last 72 years. Further, it appears that the variability in temperatures has increased as well -- the frequency in the most common temperature has decreased significantly and the curve is getting wider and flatter. 

I wonder what the actual temperatures are on the x-axis. Around a third of the temperatures from 2013-2023 are in the "extremely hot" range which seems very concerning. I think it would help interpretation and understanding if I knew the temperatures that make up this range so I could relate it to what I am experiencing. 

This relates to me and my community because global warming affects everyone. I have certainly noticed long stretches of 100+ degree days throughout the summer and it is concerning for the environment. We have also had bad droughts in northern California as another sign that the climate is changing.

 Headline: "The Earth Catching Fire"

name: Ethan
comment info:
The thing I notice is that this is the most effective visualization I have seen since looking at these graphs. The dark red getting more prevalent in the gif as time goes on is extremely striking. Further, the shift from a pretty normal distribution in 1951 to the right skew in 2013 is jarring. These two elements combined make this graph incredibly effective at portraying how summer temperatures have gotten hotter.

I wonder why this was limited to the Northern Hemisphere. The largest reason I can think of is that most NYT readers are likely in the United States, if not the Northern Hemisphere. However, from what I know this is a global issue. I know that summer in Australia and Brazil have also been getting much hotter. When clicking the citation, the data is available for the whole globe.  Was this done to make the visualization more striking? Was it done by NYT editors to keep their readers in mind?

This relates to me and my community as I can anecdotally verify the truth of this. I am from Los Angeles and throughout high school I worked at a day camp and my last two years were marked by extreme heat advisories. It would be so hot, that it was literally unsafe for us to bring our campers outside for anything besides going in the pool. This graph serves a powerful way to convey my experience to people from other parts of North America which are not subject to this extreme heat.

Headline: “Spicy Summers, We’re All Feeling Them!”

name: Alexis Gywnn Hegarty
comment info:
I notice that since average summer temperatures have increased over the last 72 years. The distribution of temperatures from 1951-1980 appear to have a normal distribution. In comparison, the temperatures from 2013-2023 seemed to be far more right skewed. I also noticed that while the higher temperatures have gotten more extreme while temperatures on the cold end stay in the same range. 

I wonder what temperature ranges correspond to "normal", "Hot", "extra hot" , etc,. The lack of specific temperature ranges make the graph harder to contextualize. Additionally, it makes it easier to be interpreted differently across viewers. I like the movement part of the graph. You can easily see the movement of the distribution across the years because the graph keeps the original data shaded in. 

This relates to me and my community because we are all affected by these higher temperatures, whether we acknowledge them or not. The higher temperatures can be dangerous in California especially because of the risk of fires and drought.

Graph Title: "Temperature Trends Overtime"

name: Jena Weitzman
comment info: The first thing that I noticed about this graph is that temperatures are rapidly increasing over time. In the first graph that is showing summer temperatures from 1951 to 1980, there is barely any red in the visual indicating extremely hot temperatures. However, there is a very large portion of the visual for 2013-2023 showing extremely hot temperatures, indicating that summer temperatures are increasing over time. The 2013 to 2023 time frame also has an alarmingly low portion of the graph that has normal or cold temperatures-- extreme values are much more common. I wonder what the actual temperatures are recorded on the x-axis. What temperature exactly qualifies as "extremely hot", and how does that compare to my own perception of what is "hot" or "cold"? This graph relates to me and my community because the topic of global warming is widely discussed today, and is becoming an increasingly pressing issue. As a young adult, I am part of the community that will be inheriting the world as we know it, and it is our job to take care of the planet that we live on before we cause even further destruction. I myself have noticed more extreme weather than I did when I was a little kid, 100 degree days are much more common than they used to be. Additionally, in California we have experienced severe droughts more often than we should. A catchy headline for this graph would be "It's Getting Hot in Here- Rising Temperatures Over Time".

Headline: "Rising Temperatures: A Planet in Flames"

name: Miguel
comment info: I noticed that over time summer temperatures have increased drastically. More specifically we observe how from 1951 to 2023 the changes in the frequency of different temperatures and the hotter temperatures are now more common. Since 1951 the most frequent among the Summer temperatures from June to August in the Northern Hemisphere was a normal temperature. However, in the present day that's changed to a hot temperature. Then in regards to the extremes back in 1951-1980, both extremely hot and extremely cold were such small portions of the graphic. In the present day both of these extremes have changed the extremely cold portion has managed to get smaller while Extremely hot has become a significant portion of the summer temperatures even becoming the second most common temperature. I wonder what many effects have contributed to this significant increase in Summer Temperatures. I would also like to know how these temperatures were recorded since it's not said by the graphic and whether it's taking the averages. This graphic can show effectively just how significant the increase in temperature has been over the past 72 years. It is a sign of concern for Earth's inhabitants as it shows past trends and ultimately gets you thinking of future trends. It makes you think of how dire the situation of global warming is and how we need to act now to try and prevent such increases from continuing. A fitting title would be: "Heating Hemisphere: Increasing Temperatures from 1950 to 2023."
